DOC.HEAD: Dom DeLuise Makes Met Opera Debut
Eds: No PMs Planned
DOC.TEXT: The Metropolitan Opera's light-hearted production of Johann Strauss' ``Die Fledermaus'' was especially effervescent in its second appearance this season. On Thursday, German baritone Hermann Prey, respected for bringing importance to weighty music, cavorted merrily and seemed to be having as good a time on stage as though really at Prince Orlofsky's Act 2 party. It was Prey's first time to sing Eisenstein at the Met. In the speaking role of Frosch, the jailer, the Met has had, in recent memory, Jack Gilford, Otto Schenk, who devised this production in 1986, and Sid Caesar. On Christmas night, in this season's first ``Die Fledermaus,'' actor-comedian Dom DeLuise made his Met debut. At the Met, singing is in German and speaking _ thus, most of the jokes _ are in English. DeLuise's timing and body language were wonderful. Traditionally, some of the jokes are changed each season. DeLuise held a beer bottle which crumbled in his hand when he sang a couple of high notes. And, he told a series of Leona Helmsley one-liners, concluding, ``She thinks she owns the place.'' DeLuise's exchanges with the excellent Franz Mazura as the jail's warden were genuinely funny. Carol Vaness sang Rosalinde, who gets the best of her husband Eisenstein in an elaborate practical joke set up by his friend Falke, well sung by Lenus Carlson. Miss Vaness also handled the flamboyance well when she pretended to be a Hungarian countess. Neil Shicoff sang a tenor who adores Rosalinde, throwing himself into the fun wholeheartedly. Barbara Kilduff sang sweetly as Adele the maid and Grace Millo sparkled as her pert sister. Brigitte Fassbaender sang Prince Orlofsky for the first time at the Met. She dressed simply for the part, red sash across a tuxedo. The distinctive edge on her speaking voice turned shrill on her sung high notes. But Miss Fassbaender commands a stage easily and is an agreeable, distinctive Orlofsky. Hermann Michael, who has been Herbert von Karajan's assistant at the Vienna State Opera and has conducted Wagner operas in Seattle, made his Met debut on Christmas day. His timing was unrushed and fine and the orchestra sounded very lyrical under his baton. Act 2 remains among the Met's most delightful sets, as the outside of Prince Orlofsky's glass conservatory room moves on the Met turntable until it becomes the room's interior, ready for dinner and lively dancing to Strauss.
